title: Direction of Electric Field at Points S, T, N

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Two conducting plates, A and B, are connected to opposite sides of a battery of potential difference <math alttext="uppercase V" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>and are separated by a distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assume that the area of the plates is very large such that the plate dimensions are large compared to the separation distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Points L and T are midway between the plates, points S and R are the same horizontal distance from point T, and point R is directly above point S. Edge effects at the points R, S, T, L, and N can be neglected. (a) What is the direction of the electric field, if any, at each of the points S, T, and N? If the electric field is zero at any of the indicated points, write “0 at the point _.”

Points L and T are midway between the plates, points S and R are the same horizontal distance from point T, and point R is directly above point S. Edge effects at the points R, S, T, L, and N can be neglected. (a) What is the direction of the electric field, if any, at each of the points S, T, and N? If the electric field is zero at any of the indicated points, write “0 at the point _.”

(b) Rank the magnitude of the electric potential differences <math alttext="delta uppercase V sub R S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>R</mi><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="delta uppercase V sub R T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>R</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="delta uppercase V sub R L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>R</mi><mi>L</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> between the pairs of points indicated by the subscripts. Use “VRS,” “VRT,” and “VRL” to indicate the given potential differences, respectively. If any of the quantities are equal, clearly indicate this. Justify your ranking by citing relevant physics principles.

(c) While the plates remain connected to the battery, the area of each plate is doubled. Does the electric field at point S increase, decrease, or remain the same compared to the electric field at point S in the initial situation? Justify your answer.

The plates are returned to their original areas. The battery provides a constant potential difference <math alttext="uppercase V" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. A small charged particle of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a magnitude of charge <math alttext="q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The particle is moving with constant speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown, when it enters the region midway between plates A and B. The particle strikes plate A at a distance <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the top of plate A. Assume gravitational forces on the particle are negligible. (d) Does the particle have a positive charge, negative charge, or no net charge? Justify your answer.

A student derives the following correct relationship to describe the motion of the particle between the plates:<math alttext="y equals the square root of the fraction, lowercase v squared times m times d squared, over q times uppercase V, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>m</mi><msup><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mi>q</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>.(e) If the magnitude of the particle’s charge is decreased, will <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> increase, decrease, or remain the same? Support your claim by referencing the equation above.

(f) By citing relevant physics principles, explain how decreasing the charge has the effect on <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that you determined in part (e).
